snippet: In the last year, mutual funds have done little to adapt to a Supreme Court decision that defines a fund’s board, not its management company, as the ultimate authority for its operations.
abstract: Mutual funds have done little to adapt to a 2011 Supreme Court decision involving Janus Capital Group that defines a fund’s board, not its management company, as the ultimate authority for its operations; industry seems content to live with the murky and potentially broad consequences of the decision, leaving investors with even more uncertainty.
lead_paragraph: In the last year, mutual funds have done little to adapt to a Supreme Court decision that defines a fund’s board, not its management company, as the ultimate authority for its operations.

headline.seo: Effects of Janus Ruling Remain a Mystery for Mutual Funds
headline.main: A Mutual Fund Ruling Remains a Head-Scratcher
headline.print_headline: A Fund Ruling Remains a Head-Scratcher
